fields.name: EGS_chp
fields.description: An enhanced geothermal system (EGS) combined heat and power plant (CHP) is a type of geothermal power plant that generates both heat and electricity by using the Earth's subsurface heat which is artificially stimulated by hydrostatic pressured heat transfer fluid. CHP is commonly accepted as a viable technology to convert from medium to high-temperature geothermal energy into both heat and electrical energy. These plants use geothermal fluids with a temperature range between 150°C and 200°C, which is suitable to generate electricity but can still be used to generate heat.

fields.name: HYDRO_chp
fields.description: A hydrothermal combined heat and power plant (CHP) is a type of geothermal power plant that generates both heat and electricity by using heat from the Earth's subsurface geothermal brine. CHP is commonly accepted as a viable technology to convert from medium to high-temperature geothermal energy into both heat and electrical energy. These plants use geothermal fluids with a temperature range between 150°C and 200°C, which is suitable to generate electricity but can still be used to generate heat.

fields.name: EGS_binary_orc
fields.description: An enhanced geothermal system (EGS) subcritical binary cycle geothermal power plant is a type of geothermal power plant that generates electricity by using heat from the Earth's subsurface which is artificially stimulated by hydrostatic pressure. The Organic Rankine Cycle (ORC) is commonly accepted as a viable technology to convert from low to medium-temperature geothermal energy into electrical energy. These plants use geothermal fluids with a lower temperature range of around 100-180°C, which is low to generate steam but can still be used to generate electricity.

fields.name: HYDRO_binary_orc
fields.description: A hydrothermal subcritical binary cycle geothermal power plant is a type of geothermal power plant that generates electricity by using heat from the Earth's subsurface to produce geothermal brine, which is then used to generate electricity through a turbine and generator. The Organic Rankine Cycle (ORC) is commonly accepted as a viable technology to convert from low to medium-temperature geothermal energy into electrical energy. These plants use geothermal fluids with a lower temperature range of around 100-200°C, which is too low to generate steam but can still be used to generate electricity.

fields.name: EGS_direct_use
fields.description: An enhanced geothermal system (EGS) Direct Use is defined as utilization of the  geothermal brine generated from an artificially stimulated reservoir through a heat exchanger for residential and space heating, district heating, agriculture (greenhouses), thermal tourism (SPAs), fish farming, snow melting, dairies (pasteurizing milk), industrial applications (textile, paper, food, and beverage, …etc.) and many other applications. Direct use of EGS resources range between 50°C and 120°C, which is suitable to generate heat.

fields.name: HYDRO_direct_use
fields.description: A hydrothermal Direct Use is defined as utilization of the geothermal fluids by using heat from the Earth's subsurface geothermal brine through a heat exchanger for residential and space heating, district heating, agriculture (greenhouses), thermal tourism (SPAs), fish farming, snow melting, dairies (pasteurizing milk), industrial applications (textile, paper, food, and beverage, …etc.) and many other applications. Direct use of hydrothermal resources range between 50°C and 120°C, which is suitable to generate heat.

fields.name: EGS_cchp
fields.pretty_name: EGS Combined Cooling Heat and Power (CCHP)
fields.description: An enhanced geothermal system (EGS) combined cooling heating and power plant (CCHP) is a type of geothermal power plant that generates refregiration, heating and electricity via geothermal brine generated from an artificially stimulated reservoir. CCHP is commonly accepted as a viable technology to convert from medium to high-temperature geothermal energy which generates electricity through a turbine and generator, heat through a heat exchanger, and cooling through an absorption chiller. These plants use geothermal fluids with a temperature range between 150°C and 200°C.

fields.name: HYDRO_cchp
fields.pretty_name: Hydrothermal Combined Cooling Heat and Power (CCHP)
fields.description: A hydrothermal combined cooling heating and power plant (CCHP) is a type of geothermal power plant that generates refregiration, heating and electricity by using heat from the Earth's subsurface geothermal brine. CCHP is commonly accepted as a viable technology to convert from medium to high-temperature geothermal energy which generates electricity through a turbine and generator, heat through a heat exchanger, and cooling through an absorption chiller. These plants use geothermal fluids with a temperature range between 150°C and 200°C.

fields.name: EGS_flash_single
fields.description: An enhanced geothermal system (EGS) single flash power plant is a type of geothermal power plant that evaporates hot geothermal fluids generated from an artificially stimulated reservoir to steam by reducing the pressure of the entering liquid and directing it through a turbine. These plants use geothermal fluids with a temperature range between 200°C and 300°C, which is suitable to generate electricity.

fields.name: HYDRO_flash_single
fields.description: An hydrothermal single flash power plant is a type of geothermal power plant that evaporates hot geothermal fluids from the Earth's subsurface geothermal brine to steam by reducing the pressure of the entering liquid and directing it through a turbine. These plants use geothermal fluids with a temperature range between 200°C and 300°C, which is suitable to generate electricity.

fields.name: EGS_flash_double
fields.description: An enhanced geothermal system (EGS) double flash power plant is a type of geothermal power plant that evaporates hot geothermal fluids generated from an artificially stimulated reservoir to steam by reducing the pressure of the entering liquid and directing it through a turbine. Then it flashes the remaining hot fluid of the first stage, separated, and fed into a dual-inlet turbine or into two separate turbines. These plants use geothermal fluids with a temperature range between 250°C and 350°C, which is suitable to generate electricity.

fields.name: HYDRO_flash_double
fields.description: A hydrothermal double flash power plant is a type of geothermal power plant that evaporates hot geothermal fluids from the Earth's subsurface geothermal brine to steam by reducing the pressure of the entering liquid and directing it through a turbine. Then it flashes the remaining hot fluid of the first stage, separated, and fed into a dual-inlet turbine or into two separate turbines. These plants use geothermal fluids with a temperature range between 250°C and 350°C, which is suitable to generate electricity.
